dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, Damir Seissembekov just announced that over 12 million smartphones have been verified in Kazakhstan—what do you make of that number?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Damir Seissembekov just announced that over twelve million smartphones have been verified in Kazakhstan-what do you make of that number?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to Seissembekov, more than 12 million smartphones and other mobile devices have been verified across the country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's a huge figure, right? And it includes not just phones people are using, but also ones sitting in warehouses and stores. They're really trying to, uh, legalize everything at once.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a huge figure, right? And it includes not just phones people are using, but also ones sitting in warehouses and stores. They're really trying to, uh, legalize everything at once.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The 12 million includes all phones stored in warehouses and available in stores, Seissembekov said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and he mentioned they're even verifying things like Wi-Fi routers and budget smartwatches for free. That's interesting—why those devices specifically?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and he mentioned they're even verifying things like Wi-Fi routers and budget smartwatches for free. That's interesting-why those devices specifically?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He noted that certain devices " such as Wi-Fi routers, budget smartwatches, and machine-to-machine (M2M) devices " are being verified free of charge.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I think it's because they're part of the broader connectivity ecosystem, you know? But he did say there are costs involved—software, databases, certifications… it's not a simple system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I think it's because they're part of the broader connectivity ecosystem, you know? But he did say there are costs involved-software, databases, certifications... it's not a simple system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is an information system. It includes software and requires constant access to a database, obtaining certifications and accreditations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and companies involved are paying taxes too, so it's not just a free-for-all. But what about the deadline extension? They pushed free verification for individuals till June 25.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and companies involved are paying taxes too, so it's not just a free-for-all. But what about the deadline extension? They pushed free verification for individuals till June twenty five.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Previously, authorities extended the deadline for free smartphone verification for individuals until June 25.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that gives people more time to adjust. And after that, if you buy an unverified phone, you can actually return it even past the usual two-week window. That's pretty consumer-friendly, surprisingly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that gives people more time to adjust. And after that, if you buy an unverified phone, you can actually return it even past the usual two-week window. That's pretty consumer-friendly, surprisingly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After that date, buyers will be able to return unverified smartphones to the seller, even if more than two weeks have passed since the purchase.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Do you think this whole white, gray, black list system will actually bring down smartphone prices, like some are suggesting?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Do you think this whole white, gray, black list system will actually bring down smartphone prices, like some are suggesting?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Smartphone prices in Kazakhstan may drop due to new 'blacklist' system

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, if gray market phones get pushed out or legalized, it might create more competition among legit sellers. But honestly, I'm skeptical—new regulations often add costs somewhere.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, if gray market phones get pushed out or legalized, it might create more competition among legit sellers. But honestly, I'm skeptical-new regulations often add costs somewhere.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: True. And the blacklist sounds strict—phones with missing IMEI numbers or altered codes get blocked entirely. That could wipe out a chunk of the cheaper market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True. And the blacklist sounds strict-phones with missing I M E I numbers or altered codes get blocked entirely. That could wipe out a chunk of the cheaper market.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The white list includes fully verified and approved devices; the gray list covers devices pending verification and temporarily allowed to connect for up to 30 days; and the black list contains devices with incorrect or altered identification codes, missing factory IMEI numbers, or those flagged by the international GSMA blacklist.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It might clean up the market, but whether it drops prices… I'm not so sure. What do you think about the international angle, like the GSMA blacklist being part of it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It might clean up the market, but whether it drops prices... I'm not so sure. What do you think about the international angle, like the G S M A blacklist being part of it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...and the black list contains devices with incorrect or altered identification codes, missing factory IMEI numbers, or those flagged by the international GSMA blacklist.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's key—it shows they're aligning with global standards, not just making up their own rules. But still, 12 million devices verified… that's a massive undertaking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's key-it shows they're aligning with global standards, not just making up their own rules. But still, twelve million devices verified... that's a massive undertaking.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And starting from a "clean slate," as Seissembekov said—it feels like a reset for how devices enter the country.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And starting from a clean slate, as Seissembekov said-it feels like a reset for how devices enter the country.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We're starting from a clean slate to legalize all smartphones imported into the country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Let's see if consumers actually benefit, or if it just means more red tape.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Let's see if consumers actually benefit, or if it just means more red tape.
